verses.verse: those who were in (Num. 14:45; 21:3; Josh. 12:14; 15:30; 19:4; Judg. 1:17) Hebron, and to all the places where David himself and his men were accustomed to (Num. 13:22; Josh. 14:13-15; 21:11-13; 2 Sam. 2:1) rove.

(The Tragic End of Saul and His Sons) Now (1 Sam. 23:22) the Philistines fought against Israel; and the men of Israel fled from before the Philistines, and fell slain on Mount (1 Chr. 10:1-12) Gilboa.
Then the Philistines followed hard after Saul and his sons. And the Philistines killed (1 Sam. 28:4) Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua, Saul’s sons.
(1 Sam. 14:49; 1 Chr. 8:33) The battle became fierce against Saul. The archers hit him, and he was severely wounded by the archers.

(2 Sam. 1:6) Then Saul said to his armorbearer, “Draw your sword, and thrust me through with it, lest (Judg. 9:54; 1 Chr. 10:4) these uncircumcised men come and thrust me through and abuse me.” But his armorbearer would not, (Judg. 14:3; 1 Sam. 14:6; 17:26, 36) for he was greatly afraid. Therefore Saul took a sword and (2 Sam. 1:14) fell on it.
And when his armorbearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his sword, and died with him.
So Saul, his three sons, his armorbearer, and all his men died together that same day.

And when the men of Israel who were on the other side of the valley, and those who were on the other side of the Jordan, saw that the men of Israel had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they forsook the cities and fled; and the Philistines came and dwelt in them.
So it happened the next day, when the Philistines came to strip the slain, that they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
And they cut off his head and stripped off his armor, and sent word throughout the land of the Philistines, to (2 Sam. 1:6, 10) proclaim it in the temple of their idols and among the people.
(Judg. 16:23, 24; 2 Sam. 1:20) Then they put his armor in the temple of the (1 Sam. 21:9) Ashtoreths, and (Judg. 2:13; 1 Sam. 7:3) they fastened his body to the wall of (2 Sam. 21:12) Beth Shan.
(Judg. 1:27) Now when the inhabitants of Jabesh Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,

(1 Sam. 11:1-13) all the valiant men arose and traveled all night, and took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth Shan; and they came to Jabesh and (1 Sam. 11:1-11; 2 Sam. 2:4-7) burned them there.
Then they took their bones and (2 Chr. 16:14; Jer. 34:5; Amos 6:10) buried them under the tamarisk tree at (2 Sam. 2:4, 5; 21:12-14) Jabesh, and fasted seven days.

(The Report of Saul’s Death) Now it came to pass after the (Gen. 50:10) death of Saul, when David had returned from (1 Sam. 31:6) the slaughter of the Amalekites, and David had stayed two days in Ziklag,

on the third day, behold, it happened that (1 Sam. 30:1, 17, 26) a man came from Saul’s camp (2 Sam. 4:10) with his clothes torn and dust on his head. So it was, when he came to David, that he (1 Sam. 4:12) fell to the ground and prostrated himself.
And David said to him, “Where have you come from?” So he said to him, “I have escaped from the camp of Israel.”

Then David said to him, (1 Sam. 25:23) “How did the matter go? Please tell me.” And he answered, “The people have fled from the battle, many of the people are fallen and dead, and Saul and (1 Sam. 4:16; 31:3) Jonathan his son are dead also.”
So David said to the young man who told him, “How do you know that Saul and Jonathan his son are dead?”

Then the young man who told him said, “As I happened by chance to be on (1 Sam. 31:2) Mount Gilboa, there was (1 Sam. 31:1) Saul, leaning on his spear; and indeed the chariots and horsemen followed hard after him.
Now when he looked behind him, he saw me and called to me. And I answered, ‘Here I am.’
And he said to me, ‘Who are you?’ So I answered him, ‘I am an Amalekite.’
He said to me again, ‘Please stand over me and kill me, for anguish has come upon me, but my life still remains in me.’

So I stood over him and (1 Sam. 31:2-4) killed him, because I was sure that he could not live after he had fallen. And I took the crown that was on his head and the bracelet that was on his arm, and have brought them here to my lord.”
Therefore David took hold of his own clothes and (Judg. 9:54; 2 Kin. 11:12) tore them, and so did all the men who were with him.

And they (2 Sam. 3:31; 13:31) mourned and wept and (2 Sam. 3:31) fasted until evening for Saul and for Jonathan his son, for the (1 Sam. 31:13) people of the LORD and for the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.
Then David said to the young man who told him, “Where are you from?” And he answered, “I am the son of an alien, an Amalekite.”
